generation: Another week has flown by. I drove by the new house yesterday and noticed the front window was covered in boxes. We may receive the keys at closing, and I'm getting increasingly excited. If all goes well this week, we'll be set for closing a week from Wednesday. I was up late last night, watching movies with Bethany until after 3:00am. There's been a lot of movie watching lately. Here's my rundown: last night we watched Thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It exceeded my expectations. Then we watched Gigli, which was just as bad as the media said, but we had to see it for ourselves.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone filled with repeats, but now there are two great new shows that I've been watching religiously for the past week. One of them is 'Blow Out,' a show with a concept that seems to have zero gay people involved, despite its title. The show revolves around hairstylist Jonathan Antin, who wants to build a second location for his popular West Hollywood salon in Beverly Hills. Normally, this wouldn't be of interest to me, but while flipping through channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan speaking in a public voice, 'I'm going to build the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' in an empty space on Rodeo Drive. His equal mix of narcissism and dullness has me hooked. Not since 'Rocco' have I found such a compelling, yet moronic, TV personality to watch.

What a week... I've developed tendonitis in my right shoulder, just under my shoulder blade. When I move my arm excessively, particularly when using a computer mouse, it's excruciating. I've had to limit my movement due to a recent marathon of updating my website and working on other online projects. As a result, I'm struggling to muster the strength to draw. Lack of sleep is exacerbating the pain. I'm not in the best spirits, but I'm optimistic about recovery. On a more positive note, my mom's surgery was successful. Her eyesight has partially returned, allowing her to see fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Although she's still largely blind, I'm hopeful she'll regain her full vision soon.

Kindness of strangers... I attempted to do laundry today with the kids in tow and quickly realized how the simplest tasks can become a chaotic ordeal. I also discovered how remarkably kind total strangers can be, simply because they feel like being sweet. It wasn't like they had ulterior motives; I was covered in kid drool and wearing my casual 'wash-day' outfit. I'm not sure I'll be bathing again anytime soon, so there wasn't even an olfactory incentive. Currently, I'm multitasking - composing this post and watching No Doubt's collected music videos, both from the comfort of my desk in my room.

It's 11:14pm MST, and I'm sitting in my bedroom, fixing the personal computer of our personnel director from work. I don't mind doing favors, but I often wonder how frequently I end up fixing someone else's computer. I'm glad to be able to show love and care for people in this way. However, I sometimes question where the line is drawn before I'm taken advantage of. The last couple of weeks, I've been staying up late reading, so I was looking forward to an early night. Instead, I realized it would be more prudent to return the computer to its owner. No rest for the weary, right? I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight, as I sit here working.

Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga. So, after the weird lunch, my confidence took a hit. I would like everyone to think before they act. Ideally, I'd like each person to make a conscious decision to think critically from the moment they wake up, and maintain that mindset throughout the day. If they're not willing to do so, I wish they would reconsider their daily activities. I'm frustrated with the lack of critical thinking in the world. I'm not claiming to be the most intelligent person, but I believe it's reasonable to expect a basic level of thoughtfulness. I'm not referring to complex issues, but rather simple, everyday decisions. Let's focus on a few specific examples for now, and save the rest for another time, if that sounds agreeable.

The mention of Robert Rubin's name is indeed reassuring. Can you think of a Bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side who possesses similar gravitas? 2. Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? Like you're sitting in math class, feeling utterly bored, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that enables you to comprehend math? You realize that you exist, and you're in math class, and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you - the fact that you're going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? I hate that. You know what else I dislike? Block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? Sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is, in my opinion, a form of cruel and unusual punishment. Anyone can see that.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned as far back as 1996 about the impending threat of the rise of a 'third Islamic state' in the subcontinent. T V Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the present Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he questions whether the fact that Rajeswar, rather than he or Mr. Advani, wrote these warnings makes them more credible. Last night in class, we discussed that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement" and the second, "displacement." Casey distinguishes that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force: we're running out of time, we've saved time, we're just in time. He argues that using place as the center of culture fosters a more grounded community. This is a rough summation, so I offer this disclaimer in case my professor or classmates read this post. Notably, this book is the first reading that has truly resonated with me.

Fall 1974: I was attempting, for what felt like the 13th time, to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I have an aversion to math, and it's safe to say I'm math-phobic. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door, only to find no one there. I returned to my studies, and just as I was finding a glimmer of understanding, the doorbell rang again. My breakthrough vanished instantly. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs - an uninvited practical joker.

We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We visited Guintubdan, La Carolota, a destination most of us had never been to before. We embarked on a trek to the falls, which took around 30 minutes, leaving us all breathless. However, the scenic view was well worth the effort. The icy water was invigorating, causing our bodies to numb from the cold. We only stayed for less than an hour before heading to the nearby waterfalls, another 30-minute trek. The trip was worth it, as the falls appeared calming and the entire scene was breathtaking. It felt like being one with nature, and the experience was almost meditative. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you feel drowsy. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. The whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature.

GOP faces criticism over recruitment tactics at naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville, prompting relocation. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, a citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville appeared to proceed normally, with nearly 200 people leaving as new Americans. Before the new citizens departed the June 29 event, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in ceremony encouraged them to visit a voter registration table, a common sight at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual, as Republican volunteers were distributing forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked to register new voters as GOP members. Linda Cross, who attended to watch her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath, found the situation suspicious. The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.

I liked the idea of that as an offense - perhaps it could have been a way to avoid being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I've been hesitant to engage in discussions about certain topics, especially those involving flags. However, since I initiated the subject, I suppose I should share my thoughts. Firstly, I believe that having a law against flag-burning is completely absurd. The moment you grant a symbol - any symbol - automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently subjective - they don't inherently represent anything; it's the perceived meaning or assigned representation that holds importance. The idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. Symbols are kind of fickle; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.

As of this review (26/10/2013), a game-breaking bug prevents the completion of a side mission, although the main storyline remains unaffected. Some gadgets are assigned to inconvenient hotkeys, requiring excessive keyboard navigation, which can disrupt combos during combat.

They essentially refined Shadow Warrior (2013), particularly the boss fights, which are now awesome. The weapons feel very nice, although not quite as exceptional as those in D44M, but still solid nonetheless. Enemies aren't overly resilient, provided you're not careless with handling elemental and upgrade aspects. The upgrade system is well-balanced, and once you grasp it, it's not too tedious. The elemental mechanics and limited ammo encourage the use of different weapons. There are many cool, unique weapons that remain viable throughout most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's contributions.

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics on all fronts, including ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, and more. I felt a stronger connection to this character as well. Although the story starts off rough, it significantly improves as you progress, a trend I've noticed in every AC game. Edward was an intriguing character, and the side characters were equally captivating. The collectibles in this game felt meaningful, unlike in previous installments, possibly due to their greater purpose in the game. While not required, they were enjoyable to obtain and rewarded in a balanced manner. The character development and storyline progression were well-executed, making the game more engaging.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is passable, provided you have the means to purchase gun parts, which is my primary concern: the pay-to-win model. If I could overlook this, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and the HRV concept is excellent. I'd prefer this game over any Call of Duty title, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you're comfortable with this model, then by all means, have fun. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, it's best to let this one pass; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death can be frustrating at times. I'm on my first playthrough and lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. A reload option at that point would have been appreciated. I've since utilized a 3rd party mod/save tool to mitigate catastrophic failures. The aiming reticule is somewhat small and the zoom feature underpowered. Despite these issues, the game has been a blast. As someone who isn't typically a zombie fan, I've found the combination of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up elements to be great. I've been playing it as often as possible, always looking to complete just one more mission or supply run before shutting down.

An absolute great strategy game. Having played every other wargame, including European Escalation and ALB, I must say this one fits well. The numerous units are a great asset. Although I'm unsure of the exact number, there's an impressive array. The graphics are beautiful, the sounds are great, and the overall gameplay is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is surprisingly entertaining. However, if you think this game is 'easy' or are new to the strategy genre, be prepared to invest time in mastering it. Don't get discouraged by losses - plan ahead, always have anti-air and anti-tank units at the ready.

I was initially skeptical about this game, and I wasn't even sure if I wanted to buy it. The concept of the portal gun and portals seemed unusual, despite my fondness for science fiction. However, I was pleasantly surprised. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal - truly amazing. While it can be cheesy at times, the humor is well-executed. Each story character has their own unique sense of humor, and their distinct personalities shine through. The level design is also impressive. Although I never played the first Portal game, I plan to do so when I have the time. Playing the sequel was what sparked my interest in the series.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet in the UK, just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others return, and are instantly recognisable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is also present. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect and very Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done, with transforming mid-fight often a necessity, woven seamlessly into combos. This sets it apart from High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. A notable distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, although some enemies, such as Seekers, require a switch to a ranged blaster.

4k+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and Neptune gear are all included. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo This is an excellent port and a great entry point for newcomers to the series. Just be aware that there's a lot of skippable dialogue. As usual, I recommend using a gamepad, but I had no issues with a keymouse/mouse setup, both of which are fully rebindable. The price is reasonable, and I wouldn't have been unhappy with a purchase. More than half the DLC is included for free, providing plenty of content to play with. Recommended for JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between action sequences. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues at release, and with the patches, the game runs smoothly. In my opinion, this is a great and enjoyable game, despite the format being somewhat frustrating, where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies after each story progression. I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, where you can play as Batman and another character. The option to use a controller for most segments and switch to mouse and keyboard for tank combat was a welcome feature. Driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, including chasing APC commanders, is enjoyable once you master the braking system to navigate corners. Mastering this skill makes driving around the city a truly enjoyable experience.

Damn fine aaa fps shooter - that's the bottom line. It's visually stunning, sounds great, and plays exceptionally well - great fps mechanics, a nice story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint hearted though - some of those cutscenes were pretty darn cruel and vivid. But when a game overall is so great, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as I saw them: - no SLI support, which is surprising. I had to put the game away until I upgraded my card, as it ran poorly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Ensure you have a fairly decent single-GPU card. - Some small obstacles are frustratingly unclimbable, which seems illogical.

English is not my native language, as I am Dutch. Please disregard any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into several categories: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, and replayability. 

Graphics: The game features a comic-like style, with very slick graphics that lack unnecessary details. The color schemes are nice, and the overall aesthetic works well for the game. The graphics can be set to 'high' without putting excessive strain on your system. I run the game on an i5 Pentium processor, with an Nvidia GeForce 710m card and 8GB of memory, and it runs smoothly (Windows 8.1).

- controls: The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, but also with an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I've invested in this game that I thoroughly enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from the Call of Duty series would be. However, don't buy this game thinking it's similar to Call of Duty, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. I've lost count of how many times I hear new players express frustration and complain about getting killed quickly. It's not uncommon to get shot and die, just like in real life. Edit: After playing this game for a while now and investing a significant amount of money, I can say it's one of the best multiplayer games around. It's a great alternative to play when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm 2 hours in and thoroughly enjoying this game. The humor is hilarious. Gameplay is solid, art design is beautiful, music is surprisingly high quality and fitting, the story/world has me intrigued, and the puzzles are entertaining. The comedy is the standout feature, with jokes, parodies, and references that will resonate with anyone who's played RPGs since their inception. Even newcomers to the genre will appreciate the humor. If you've played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you owe it to yourself to play this game - the nods to these classics are undeniable. I had to pause after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far. The game's lighthearted nature is a breath of fresh air, making it a must-play for fans of the genre.

I'm really sorry, I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I didn't enjoy this game. The description seemed appealing, but the execution fell short. As a fan of puzzle and exploration games, I found this game to be completely unintuitive. Despite looking up how to progress, I still didn't find the gameplay enjoyable. The lack of a pause button is a significant oversight, especially with timed sequences. I also feel like the game is heavy on cut scenes, leaving me waiting and unengaged for extended periods. I love puzzle and exploration games, but this one didn't meet my expectations. The description sounded right up my alley, but it didn't translate to a fun experience. Considering the timed sequences, a pause button seems essential. I end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.

This game is truly breathtaking. From its captivating storyline to its stunning graphics, I was completely enthralled. The narrative wasn't just a generic tale, but rather an immersive experience that made me feel like I was the protagonist, trying to unravel the mysteries of the story. The gameplay was exceptional, and I gained valuable insights about myself, particularly my unexpected fear of heights, which was triggered by the ice caverns. My anxiety was palpable, but I persevered for Uncle Fred's sake. I would be thrilled to see a DLC or sequel, and I would be the first to purchase and recommend it to everyone I know. Thank you to the entire team involved in creating this masterpiece; you've truly crafted a beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to achieve a specific goal or 'victory'. Unlike previous games, which followed the Earth's timeline through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age, this game takes place in the future, where you're on a mission to colonize a new planet. I appreciate that 2K took a new approach to the game, introducing mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. However, these additions sometimes made the game feel overwhelming. One potential improvement could be incorporating new artwork, such as the environment experienced when communicating with another leader. The game's core remains engaging, but some refinements could enhance the overall experience. The affinity system and orbital layer add depth, but may require time to fully grasp.

Great game with tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience. Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. After 60+ hours of gameplay, I can confidently say this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games. Its design is reminiscent of a survival horror, where you must conserve ammo, heal your wounds, and take medication when infected. The zombies feel natural and are well-animated, especially for a free-to-play game. I highly recommend playing with 1 or 2 friends, but the community is super friendly, making it easy to make friends or chat with others via voice comms.

02/07/2014 - Unfortunately, I'm unable to wholeheartedly recommend or enjoy this game due to two major issues that detract from the experience. Firstly, the lack of Australian servers results in a severe disadvantage, with even a single red bar causing unbearable lag. Notably, I encountered stuttering and lag during offline training mode, which is perplexing. The poor ping further exacerbates the problem, ultimately ruining the game. Everything is plagued by artifacts - menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never experienced this issue with my graphics card before, so I suspected it might be related to my overclock. However, resetting my GPU to stock settings made no difference.

I finished this late last night. Although the story isn't particularly deep or engaging, the storytelling is what sets it apart. The atmosphere is richly detailed, and the numerous collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I gained valuable insight into the world of Batman, which made the limited number of bosses somewhat disappointing. However, future games can rectify this. The combat strikes a good balance of challenge, albeit on the easier side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying. The gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign add nice new gameplay mechanics. Getting access to previously unreachable places creates a nice sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for 'To the Moon'! Never before have I been so emotionally invested, feeling both depressed and fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion. The soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. The humor of the game is great, complementing the narrative without intruding upon its distinguished nature. The 'Doctor Who' references are endless, adding another layer of depth to the game.

Bastion is a bloody brilliant game, boasting a really great storyline. Set after a calamity has occurred, you begin to rebuild on the bastion. The game offers a considerable amount of choice, allowing you to decide what to build to gain an advantage, which weapons to use, and what power-ups to equip them with, as well as selecting drinks that provide bonus effects. The art style and music are fantastic, with vibrant visuals that defy the typical dullness associated with apocalyptic settings. Notably, the game features dynamic narration that responds to the player's actions. For instance, if you pick up a weapon and then switch to another in the armoury, the narration will acknowledge the change, commenting on your new choice of weapon.

I initially purchased this game during its early development phase, when the sole currency was spacebux and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game truly shone. At that point, all guns were equally overpowered, eliminating any balance issues; players could engage and defeat each other at will. The game also offered unlimited gun slots and five loadouts, allowing for extensive customization. Given the game's claim of having 'bajillions of guns', it's surprising that players are limited to just six weapon slots and three loadouts before having to make a purchase. I once had an impressive collection of guns, spanning three pages, and was brainstorming new ideas, as that's where I found the most enjoyment.

This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews reflect the fun of this neat little game. It is an odd mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and it pulls it off with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't normally enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface are oddly charming. As such, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I recently started playing, and I'm thoroughly enjoying this game. With my headphones on, I become completely immersed in the game for hours on end. It's been a while since a game has had such a profound effect on me. The music effectively sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate every combat encounter, and the developers have optimized combat exceptionally well. Initially, I had doubts about the naval combat system, but it's incredibly fun to take down multiple fleets simultaneously. The only way to lose is by failing to retreat. If combat appears overwhelming, simply retreat, regroup, and launch a counter-assault. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about significant changes for the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it's undoubtedly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DmC serves as the perfect entry point for newcomers to jump into the series. It showcases the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and chronicles his transformation from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he's introduced into the corrupt world he had willfully chosen to ignore, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness, making him a more relatable character.

Where do I start with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is absolutely charming, with meticulous attention to detail, making it a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It strikes a perfect balance between seriousness and humor. The character design is impeccable, featuring diverse characters with unique personalities and secrets. What sets it apart from other RPGs is the absence of violence, a refreshing concept in the genre. Drawing inspiration from Earthbound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, it's clear that this game is something special. The soundtrack is equally impressive, easily the best I've heard in a long time. The game's charm and character design make it stand out, with various characters and secrets to discover.

I am recommending this solely because it's free, and might be a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor, which failed to elicit a reaction from me. I may be desensitized, or perhaps it was too simplistic to warrant an emotional response. The other half of the game attempts to portray a person's mental decline through various themes, including obsession, hallucination, and depression. In theory, it's an intriguing concept. However, the game took me only 10 minutes to complete, even with thoroughly reading and absorbing every detail.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps aside, allowing you to take the reins. It's an engaging way to challenge your mind while still being entertaining. Although this game isn't as story-driven, it did give birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when I'm feeling bored, and I love to revisit it to see what sparked a legend and what has become a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is relatively simple to explain. You utilize portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two types of buttons are in the game: one that you press directly and one that requires a cube to be placed on it.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally experienced only two: one minor and the other quite annoying), I can definitely recommend this space exploration game. Both bugs have since been resolved, with one fix increasing my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120. As most reviews focus on specs, I'll share mine: i5 6600k (~200â‚¬), Radeon RX480 (~200â‚¬), Z170 Pro Gaming (~150â‚¬), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70â‚¬), totaling ~650â‚¬, which falls within the medium price range. Although my rig is relatively new, I consistently achieve 60+ FPS on high settings with VSync enabled, which contradicts the numerous comments claiming overkill setups yet experiencing only 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? It's been that long since an RTS game of such quality has been released. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes awfully close to becoming my personal favorite RTS game. Combining this with a huge Risk-like grand strategy mode hits the spot. I try not to be overly biased, but the fact that this game allows you to transform into a dragon, supporting, attacking, and commanding unit production, direction, and spawning simultaneously, is a significant draw. I do enjoy complicated RTS games, such as Civilization V. However, such games often attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources into one complicated game mode, which can be overwhelming. The ability to turn into a dragon and aid troops is a unique feature that sets Divinity apart.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The solid retro graphics and pleasant music combine to form truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script seamlessly transitions from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, often simultaneously, while cleverly subverting RPG tropes. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you enjoy RPGs, play this game. If you appreciate video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours, play this game.

I've had this game for just a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, and their engagement is evident in the discussion forums and dev diaries. Although the game's mechanics have a fairly steep learning curve, which I'm still trying to master, this depth of strategy offers numerous ways to achieve goals and capitalize on situations. The game, in my opinion, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself fully immersed in every session, regardless of the play-through's progression.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the initial few hours of play. However, after this period, you'll start to notice that the game's offerings are limited to repetitive combat, enemies, and gameplay. A significant high point is the developers' dedication to regular updates, which often include substantial content additions, such as sweeping system changes, new warframes, and various tweaks and features. It's suitable for casual play. Although, I doubt it will maintain your interest beyond a few months unless you enjoy grinding. The game's free-to-play model is a significant advantage. I recommend trying it out, especially if you're looking for a quick gaming fix.

This game is extremely dull. I purchased it, believing it to be a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it falls short of expectations. The gameplay involves absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb more. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels lack inventiveness, and the overall experience is a surreal and unsettling horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show, but rather one that evokes feelings of depression and existential dread. Every 'living' creature in the game, from small pets to human beings, raises questions about the creators' fascination with taxidermy. The game's atmosphere is far from the lighthearted and quirky experience I was expecting.

Alright. Let me explain a few things, as someone very interested in politics, I was intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, 'oh wow, a simulator of the road to becoming president, that sounds fun!' However, it didn't quite live up to my expectations. The game begins by asking you to choose a side: Republican or Democrat, with no option for Independent or third-party affiliation. A little disappointed, but still optimistic, I continued to see what I could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is enjoyable to experiment with. It's the only time you have the option to wear your head or not in a campaign, literally. The game starts you off and says you need to pick a side, there is no other option. I carried on to see what I could do, and I thought the character customization was pretty fun to mess around with.

My stats (at the time of writing this review): 
- 8.6 hours to complete the game 
- 10 collectibles found out of 25 
- zero achievements out of 15 

What I liked: 
- The visuals were impressive up until the last level (ice caves) 
- Although the story was not great, the ending (after the closing credits) somewhat redeemed my time spent playing the game 

What I disliked: 
- The visuals in the last level were uninteresting 
- The gameplay in the last level became significantly harder, making it a frustrating experience of repetition until I got it right

Pros: +graphics. Cons: -bugs, particularly environmental issues, can cause players to become stuck or encounter invisible walls despite having a clear line of sight to enemies. -The game holds the player's hand, making it feel overly guided. -Enemy AI is underwhelming. -Enemies often seem to have knowledge of the player's location upon being spotted. -Enemies possess unrealistic accuracy, reminiscent of the first Ghost Warrior, which can be frustrating. -Checkpoint and save systems are poorly implemented. -The storyline is unengaging and lacks interest. I wouldn't recommend this game unless it's heavily discounted, even then it feels like a chore to play solely to finish it and move on to the next game in my library. Given the time wasted on the first Ghost Warrior, which was equally uninteresting and felt liberating to finish, I'm unlikely to see this game through to the end.

Review for 29/11/2015: Avoid purchasing this game due to frequent server outages, rendering it unplayable. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. During my brief time playing, I enjoyed the experience. As the Steve Miller Band song goes: "Go on take the money and run..." https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 --- English - 73 minutes playing the game. Initially, I was impressed, but some guns seem overpowered and matchmaking can be unfair. However, I've experienced worse in BF3, where new players were often matched with higher-level players who seemed invulnerable, even when shot in the face.

It's not hard for me to see why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't my cup of tea. As a Vive owner, I prefer playing room-sized games with controllers. Initially, the game's vast universe is awe-inspiring, but I found that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and time required to do anything interesting at the start were too steep for me. Perhaps with more patience and gaming time, this would be compelling. However, I don't have either luxury, and there are plenty of other VR games I'd rather spend my time on. The game's scale, while impressive, ultimately felt like a hindrance.

Hands down, my all-time favorite first-person shooter. However, this game isn't for run-and-gun enthusiasts. Recoil and ballistics are remarkably realistic. A single hit to the chest, neck, or head from a rifle-caliber weapon is often fatal, unless it's just a graze. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are necessary to stay on target. There's no infinite ammunition pool. If you frequently reload mid-magazine, you'll end up with a pouch full of partially used magazines. You can't sprint indefinitely. After a prolonged run, your aim will suffer as you catch your breath. To steady your aim, rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill. Accuracy still suffers when standing, but controlled bursts and resting your weapon can help. Rounds drop over distance and single hits can be fatal.

I didn't purchase EU when it first came out, instead buying it on sale, which included EW. As a result, I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had with the game. I thoroughly enjoyed it, finding it challenging in the early stages but rewarding when executed correctly. As for XCOM2, I'm a big fan - the game runs smoothly on medium settings with my GTX560 and 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game was set to high, resulting in some sluggish performance, but it wasn't unplayable. Dropping it down to medium resolved the issue. I'm not sure if I'm just fortunate when it comes to avoiding game issues, but many negative reviews seem to stem from an entitled mindset. The game plays well for me, and I've had a positive experience overall.

+rpg levelling +wide-variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humored -grind intensive (if under utilizing the civvy station types) -sub-par ai teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of levelling skills (that is, no branching) This game is incredibly enjoyable. Despite the drawbacks, there's still variety and strategy to be found. The pace is fast from the start and only accelerates. Although equipment options are limited, there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. To extend the game's lifespan, mods are the way to go. Fight for Universe is the standout, but Big Fight for Beef is also noteworthy. The game's fun factor remains high, with plenty of opportunities for progression and exploration.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued. Anti-globalisation campaigners have cancelled a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEF's event in Davos, which is expected to attract a more affluent crowd.

Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal. Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to resolve a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. GM, whose European operations are struggling financially, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, following Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The US firm is thought to be offering approximately $2 billion (Â£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.

Cardinal criticises Iraq war, stating billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East could have been better utilised to alleviate poverty. Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor made these remarks on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance during his Christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used his Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of resources. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out against the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, rather than being used to bring people out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease. The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history poverty".

British stars denied major Oscars. British hopes of winning major Oscars were dashed as UK stars failed to secure acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's 'Vera Drake' failed to take the director or screenplay awards, and there was no prize for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost to Best Actress Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to win Best Supporting Actor awards. The UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film award for her gritty drama 'Wasp'. Arnold, a former presenter of children's television shows 'Number 73' and 'Motormouth' in the 1980s, described her win as "totally overwhelming". 'Wasp' tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer behind the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it achieved a record-breaking worldwide gross of over $60m (Â£31.3m) for an independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and progressed through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 1970s that were more commonly held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression as fast web access encourages more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of Britain's broadband users regularly upload content and maintain personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. Having an always-on, fast connection is transforming the way people use the internet. Over five million UK households have broadband, with this number growing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's internet habits. It found that more than half of broadband users logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, the report argues, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online, with a fast connection changing the way people use the internet.

Yukos is set to appear in a US court on Thursday as it continues its fight for survival. The Russian oil and gas company is being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27 billion (Â£14 billion) tax bill. In an attempt to utilize international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas, Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US. Despite this, the unit was sold to state oil firm Rosneft for $9.4 billion, following a disrupted state auction. Yukos' lawyers now argue that the auction breached US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any company that acquires its assets, employing all available legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site as voting gets underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but the official site experienced a temporary closure due to an overwhelming influx of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and reports that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life. However, less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing' - The China Three Gorges Project Corp is reportedly refusing to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, according to the Chinese state press. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the Xiluodu Dam, a sister project, as stated by the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to stop due to inadequate environmental checks. The Beijing News suggests that the company may opt to pay a fine instead. The firm has also disregarded orders to cease construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which deflected off Richard Dunne and found the net, putting United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. United's approach play was initially laboured, but they managed to fashion a chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar. However, they eventually secured the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race.

Ferguson hails Manchester United's resolve. Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and determination, refusing to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also commended senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which few other players possess.

A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. 'A Different Story' will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, running from 10-20 February. The film features the singer discussing his career and personal life, from his Wham! days to more recent events. George Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and Executive Producer Andy Stephens will also be in attendance. The 93-minute film sees Michael reflecting on his early Wham! days, his later career, and his high-profile battles with Sony.

Downloads enter US singles chart; digital music downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's 'Boulevard of Broken Dreams' is currently number two in Billboard's pop chart and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up the new Hot 100 chart. The second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales, but confines its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music, with no changes to the existing digital chart.

Anti-spam laws have taken a significant toll on the self-declared "spam king" of the internet, who is now seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the mastermind behind Optinrealbig.com and the originator of billions of junk mail messages, stated that lawsuits have forced his company into Chapter 11. Optinrealbig was embroiled in several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company claims that filing for Chapter 11 will enable it to resolve its legal issues while continuing to operate. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, Optinrealbig was sued in December 2003 for violating anti-spam laws. The lawsuit, brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen Denies Rift with Santini. Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has denied that Coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. Newspaper speculation had suggested that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "The sole reason for his resignation is his own personal problems." He recently spoke to me about this matter, stating it was personal. Arnesen was unable to shed light on the problems that led to Santini's departure after just 13 games in charge. "Jacques has never disclosed the exact nature of his issues," he said. "I trust him, and we must respect his decision.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the win. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to hosting England at Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give coach Matt Williams his first Six Nations victory when Italy visit Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

Economy to be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, says Chancellor Gordon Brown. He made the statement after cabinet members held their final meeting at No 10 before the expected election announcement. Brown expressed confidence that voters would acknowledge Labour's role in bringing stability and growth, and would continue to do so. The Tories, meanwhile, unveiled plans to tackle "yob culture", while the Lib Dems provided further details on their proposals to replace council tax. In a separate development, the Archbishop of Canterbury penned an open letter to the three parties, urging them to refrain from exploiting people's fears during the election. He cautioned against turning the election into a competition about who can most effectively instil fear in voters regarding terrorism, asylum, and crime. The Archbishop's letter came as the parties prepare for the expected election announcement.

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's championships in Sheffield. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not participate in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will aim to secure his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in outstanding form on the European circuit in recent weeks, establishing himself as one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter. His performance suggests he is likely to secure a spot in Madrid. Meanwhile, Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European championships, with Carroll currently ranked third in the world 3000m ranking and Cragg occupying the top spot.

Robinson eyes dual code success as England rugby union captain Jason Robinson targets a historic win over Australia on Saturday. A former rugby league international who switched codes in 2000, Robinson will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. Later, at 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will face Australia in the tri-nations tournament final. "Securing victories in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England can seal their third autumn international win, following successive victories over Canada and South Africa, and avenge June's 51-15 loss to the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of failure against Australia with a win at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Net users are advised to avoid a scam website claiming to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate, utilizing an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with the fake site and has reported it to the authorities. This is the latest in a series of scams exploiting the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The website link is contained in a spam email currently circulating, with a subject line reading "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal." The email's text is riddled with poor grammar and spelling, characteristic of phishing attempts. The DEC has no connection with the fake site and says it has contacted the police about it.

Iraq to Invite Phone Licence Bids. Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licences, aiming to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. The Ministry of Communications has invited bids from local, Arab, and foreign companies. The winning bidder will partner with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to 25% within 10 years. It also hopes to develop a highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector. The bidding and tender process details will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. A road-show for investors is also planned in Amman, Jordan, to attract potential bidders.

More women are taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks increased by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for net security firm Preventon, indicates that security messages are resonating with a diverse group of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those buying home internet security programs are retired, with this figure rising by an average of 13.2% over the last three years. Notably, more retired women (53%) are purchasing security software than retired men. The research reflects the evolving stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the heightened risks associated with high-speed broadband internet connections.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, a vast space to fill. However, an increasing number of iPod owners are utilizing this space for audio content created by a diverse range of producers. This phenomenon is known as "podcasting," with former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry being its strongest proponent. Although podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, it is not necessary to own one to create or listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show created by podcasters, typically from the comfort of their own home, using a microphone, a PC, and editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them for free. It is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former mtv host and vj (video jockey) adam curry. They need only a microphone, a pc, and some editing software.

Andrea Levy, the Orange Prize winner, has seen her novel 'Small Island' win the Whitbread Novel of the Year award. She is now the favourite to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's 'The Line of Beauty'. Geraldine McCaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for 'Not the End of the World'. All category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries a Â£25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will meet on 25 January to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Levy's novel is currently 6/4 favourite to win, according to bookmaker William Hill.

Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the relatively unknown firm that has acquired its primary asset. Yukos intends to sue Baikal and other parties involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking $20 billion in damages. In response to Russia's disregard for a US court order blocking the sale last week, Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to freeze Baikal's assets. The background and motivations of Baikal remain unclear. Russian newspapers have alleged that Baikal, which purchased the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion at a state-orchestrated auction on Sunday, has strong ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts sealed their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livi box and Miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, delivering a precise cross to the back post where McAllister timed his run perfectly to head past Meldrum, doubling the home side's lead with just 10 minutes on the clock.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers to rent massive computing power by the hour. The Sun Grid costs users $1 per hour for processing and storage power on Sun-maintained systems. Grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company that views computing capacity as a commodity on par with hardware and software. Sun draws parallels between grid computing and the development of electricity. According to Sun's Chief Operating Officer, Jonathan Schwartz, the system could mature similarly to utilities like electricity and water. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California. The service offers customers a flexible and cost-effective solution for their computing needs.

Scotland's Justice Minister has issued a warning to bigoted soccer fans, stating her intention to ban them from matches, effectively hitting them "where it hurts most." Cathy Jamieson revealed that exclusion orders are among the measures being considered as part of the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue. However, the minister emphasized that stopping sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches remains a key objective. Ms Jamieson made these comments ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week, Ms Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT The Tykes have bolstered their squad with the loan signings of Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, with Kevin Sorrell coming in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley was given the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future as the fixed line phone in your home may soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people are relying on their mobile phones for every call they make or receive. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use a mobile. The primary reason for retaining a fixed line phone is the lower call charges, but most respondents believe the future of communication lies in mobile technology. The Nokia-sponsored research highlights distinct usage patterns for mobiles and fixed phones. Home phones are preferred for longer conversations, whereas mobile calls tend to be shorter, often between mobile users and friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents cited cost as the reason for opting for their fixed phone, as it remains cheaper than using a mobile.

A group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair to reform the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber, where 70% of members would be elected. Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats, MPs and peers have failed to reach an agreement on reform. The group is confident it can garner support for removing the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government had postponed plans to abolish the remaining hereditary peers, citing low chances of success due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions that Labour's manifesto will include proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords. The group's plan aims to break the reform deadlock.

Disappointed Scott makes a solid start. Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a promising debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final, having won his heat in 7.64secs but running 0.04secs slower in the final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it needs refilling, even when it still contains ink. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer manufacturer, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges utilize chip technology to detect low ink levels and advise users to make a change. However, the suit alleges that the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of their actual ink levels.

Roxy Music to Perform at Isle of Wight Festival. Roxy Music will join Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild at the Isle of Wight Music Festival in June. REM have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will perform on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is currently working on new material in the studio, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music were formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's Virginia Plain, with other hits including Street Life, Love Is the Drug, and the 1981 John Lennon cover, Jealous Guy.

Captains line up for aid match - Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is among four Six Nations captains selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami also join the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. The game promises to be a great spectacle.

Sideways dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. The film was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, alongside writing partner Jim Taylor. Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen received acting awards for their performances. Sideways is expected to perform well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, honor films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Catalina Sandino Moreno took Best Actress for her role in the Colombian drama Maria Full of Grace. Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for Maria Full of Grace. The Independent Spirit Awards recognize outstanding achievements in independent filmmaking. Other notable winners were also recognized for their contributions.

Prince Crowned 'Top Music Earner'. Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, surpassing artists like Madonna and Elton John in Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer generated $56.5m (Â£30.4m) from concerts, album sales, and publishing royalties, largely due to his Musicology tour and album. He narrowly edged out Madonna, who earned $54.9m (Â£29.5m) from her global Re-Invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel secured 10th place, with their comeback tour contributing to earnings of $24.9m (Â£13.4m) last year. "Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3m (Â£48.5m) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

Wal-mart fights back at accusers as two big US names launch advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer, Wal-mart, has taken out over 100 full-page adverts in national newspapers to counter criticism. The group aims to address concerns over its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is planning a campaign to refute "false" claims about its product Prozac. Wal-mart initiated the battle with adverts in prominent newspapers, including The Wall Street Journal, featuring an open letter from company president Lee Scott. He emphasized that it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth," stating, "there are many misconceptions circulating about Wal-mart, but facts are facts.

Tories have outlined policing plans, proposing that local communities elect their own area police commissioner. Under these plans, unveiled by the Conservatives, the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. Party leader Michael Howard stated that the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats expressed concerns that the plan could allow extreme groups to control policing, while Labour criticized the "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. The chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, Jan Berry, emphasized the importance of retaining operational independence. She cautioned, "Policing is a service, not a political football to be kicked around during elections. These plans risk allowing individuals with extreme political views to dictate ground-level operations.

At a glance: Tory health checks. The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: individuals moving to the UK from outside the EU to live and work will be subject to health checks. Those planning to stay six months or more and originating from countries with high TB rates will be required to undergo a chest x-ray and additional tests if necessary. All non-EU nationals seeking to stay a year or more will undergo a comprehensive medical examination. This will include tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test result will automatically lead to visa application rejection. Other conditions will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes - has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic encounter in Paris? The Welsh revival has sparked optimism, with many wondering if it can continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978. These questions are on the minds of not just Wales supporters, but rugby fans worldwide, following a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two Grand Slam-winning sides in the 1970s, praised it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer, described it as "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in". A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "there was a French half and there was a Welsh half".

Manchester rock band Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their new release, Some Cities. The trio has replaced flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the number one spot. Their album follows the single Black and White Town, which peaked at number six. In the singles chart, R&B star Nelly has taken the top spot with Over and Over, a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, alongside Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, (Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame, entered the chart at number three, narrowly beating Girls Aloud's Wake Me Up. Akon's Locked Up is at number five, while Kaiser Chiefs have secured their second chart hit at number six with Oh My God.

Davies favours Gloucester future. Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with English side Gloucester, despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to remain at his current club. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. Having been left in the cold following the summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region, Davies was forced to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he gained match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he previously expressed anger over the way he was treated.

Cabinet ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. In his pre-budget report on Thursday, Gordon Brown reallocated Â£512m from central to local government budgets. Mr Raynsford revealed that he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. However, he emphasized that local governments must deliver good services without significant council tax increases. The central government cash is part of a Â£1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, a crucial goal in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr Raynsford noted that nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in well-run local authorities, as they rely on them to deliver various services.

Israeli club look to Africa for talent, with four African players, including Zimbabwe goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin are the first Arab side to compete in European competition and will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin defeat Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro recently moved to Israel after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and are based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. They have a strong ethos and are high-profile promoters of peace and co-operation within Israel.

A new report suggests that lowering the drink-drive limit could save more lives than initially thought. Research by University College London claims that reducing the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would result in 65 lives saved annually. The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, come as MPs prepare to vote on the government's Road Safety Bill. Although the bill includes changes to speeding fines, it does not address the drink-drive limit. According to transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, lowering the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003, saving the country Â£119m annually. The research was carried out by Professor Allsop. His estimates surpass a 1998 Department of Transport document, which suggested that such a move could save 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64Ã—64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1Ã—1 Î¼m^2 diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region. The array design provides a large detection area of 512Ã—512 Î¼m^2. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline, thereby eliminating the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC, fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process, consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality was successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting, demonstrating its effectiveness.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. We propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that incentivizes AVs to adopt system-optimal routing by offering toll savings. Meanwhile, user equilibrium-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level. The lower level utilizes a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model, accounting for a mixed fleet of AVs and human-driven vehicles.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This capability has not only led to the manipulation of increasingly larger objects into a regime of quantum behavior but also sparked ideas for utilizing mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, as well as precision force sensors that surpass the standard quantum limit.
