However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to a broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals suggested overcoming this limitation by establishing strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems have been achieved, but they have yet to access nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews offer product evaluations to inform customer decisions. However, these evaluations can be compromised by fake reviews, or "spams," created by professional spammers who continually adapt and refine their spamming strategies to evade detection. Capturing these strategies is challenging due to their rapid evolution over time, variation across spammers and target products, and often unknown nature. Moreover, existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which may not align with the ultimate goal of maintaining trustworthy product evaluations. To address these challenges, we propose a minimax game framework where spammers and spam detectors engage in a competitive dynamic, with objectives that extend beyond mere detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game yield stable detectors that are robust against diverse detection strategies. Spamming strategies are hard to capture, as they can be varying quickly along time, different across spammers and target products, and more critically, remained unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not well-aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address the challenges, we formulate a minimax game where the spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical goals that are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employed the Lewis-Riesenfeld method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the Lewis-Riesenfeld invariant. Among this family, we identified a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas, with the Lewis-Riesenfeld method providing a precise control over the transfer process.

In this paper, we examine the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of gaussian mixture models with a variable number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even in well-separated mixtures. We demonstrate that all local minima exhibit a common structural form, partially identifying the component centers of the true mixture. Specifically, each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single gaussian to multiple true components. Our findings hold under a certain separation condition for the true mixture components and remain valid regardless of whether the number of components is over- or under-specified. For gaussian mixtures with three components, we derive more precise results concerning the scaling with the separation between the components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $x_m$ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, Berglund-HÃ¼bsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, utilizes another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by a dual group $g^t$. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, a generalization of the study of human gait was made from existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. This hybrid model combines a metabolic energy minimization strategy with a non-linear description of the mass center's libration movement, aiming to replicate the walk-run transition behavior. Experimental data results for various speed regimes indicate that the mass center's trajectory perimeter is a relevant quantity in quantifying this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories at the Manuela BeltrÃ¡n University in BogotÃ¡, Colombia, to validate the findings.

We present a novel mixed variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems, capable of fully resolving close encounters. This method employs a time regularisation technique, preserving the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during planetary encounters. By utilising a high-order mvs scheme, large time steps can be taken when planets are far apart. Our algorithm successfully resolves near-exact collisions, with mutual separations of a fraction of the physical radius, using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed systems like the solar system. We demonstrate the long-term behaviour of our integrator on a system of six super-Earths undergoing strong scattering over 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods, such as Mercury, and show that for an equivalent computational cost, we achieve significantly better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a crucial resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In practice, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is challenging due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to system size. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise, making it a more efficient option.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a distinct multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We devise a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric, exhibiting a more complex multipolar structure that offers a means to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. Our analysis reveals numerical evidence that all multipole moments are generally larger in absolute value than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates impose only mild constraints on fuzzballs, whereas future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the LISA space mission will significantly enhance these bounds.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a complex concept in various domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We focus on a common scenario where edges represent either short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long-term edges are often manually specified by humans, which can be costly and suboptimal for downstream tasks. To address these challenges, we propose a model that leverages temporal point processes and variational autoencoders to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication patterns. By driving between-node feature propagation through temporal attention, our approach offers greater flexibility while avoiding the drawbacks associated with human-specified edges, such as high production costs and potential suboptimality.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are reported. The pcw consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. This research provides a foundation for evaluating the impact of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of pcws, given the pcw's design for near-field atom trapping. The long-term goal is to establish strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the gms of the pcw, enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms between these groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in these splittings stems from equivariant stable homotopy theory, where the equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor. Consequently, the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects result in a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The shape and amplitude of this suppression, which are poorly constrained, represent a significant source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys, such as Euclid or LSST. In the first of a two-part series, we utilize simulations to construct a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and its corresponding covariance matrix, both of which are corrected for baryonic effects using the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Furthermore, we develop an emulator to rapidly predict the baryonic power suppression, enabling us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\lambda$CDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, are among the most challenging audio files to process. Building speech processing models that can handle a wide variety of conditions would be particularly useful for language acquisition studies, where researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring the effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. We gathered diverse child-centered corpora, totaling 260 hours of recordings and covering 10 languages, to support this endeavor.

Density-based clustering relies on linking groups to specific features of the underlying probability distribution. By referencing a true, yet unknown, population structure, the clustering problem can be framed in a standard inferential setting. Here, ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation, known as modal clustering, establishes a correspondence between groups and the domains of attraction of density modes. To implement this approach, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and proper selection of the amount of smoothing is crucial. This selection governs the shape of the density and, consequently, the modal structure, ultimately identifying the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between the Standard Model and higher-dimensional operators that parameterize the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes pose an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the leading contribution to the total diboson rate correction to cancel. Carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles can "resurrect" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable generated solely by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a primary objective of numerous data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, traditional academic statistics has often been skeptical of data analyses with a causal focus. The emergence of the term "data science" presents a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis, allowing it to seamlessly incorporate causal inference from observational data. Similar to previous frameworks, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three task classes: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction, which encompasses causal inference. A clear classification of data science tasks is essential for discussing the data, assumptions, and analytics required for each task's success. We argue that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a source of widespread misunderstandings about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (wgc) necessitates the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The conventional understanding is that these particles ensure extremal black holes are unstable or marginally stable, but the implications of their absence are unclear. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously proven quantum information theorems regarding entanglement entropy. Resolving this contradiction yields a nonperturbative version of the wgc, which aligns with the standard statement at weak coupling. The argument is general, relying solely on the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography, without requiring supersymmetry or a specific UV completion.

Understanding the emergence of unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures in strongly correlated two-dimensional systems is a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2d fermi gases have emerged as ideal model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality. Despite this, direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. We demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2d fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids, providing a clean and controllable model system.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) serve as a mathematical model in various application areas, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, due to their intuitive appeal in modeling. Despite their widespread use, the frequent absence of analytic solutions makes estimating ODE parameters from data challenging, particularly for models with numerous variables and parameters. This paper proposes a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is both fast and accurate, even for models with multiple parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model using a state-space model based on the equations of a numeric solver, enabling fast estimation by avoiding computations of the entire numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained through a variational Bayes method, specifically the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes exhibit a strong dependence on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. The influence of a chiral chemical potential, namely the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, significantly affects the junction's transport characteristics. Notably, a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection is observed in the two WSM regions, with the spin polarization being opposite in the two regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been used in a number of applications. Importantly, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However, a concern for the use of the method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. Here we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of up to 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity remains relatively stable, with only a slight decrease of about 10% over the following year, demonstrating its potential for long-term applications.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, grounded in the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Furthermore, singular configurations can be identified as n_f=1 baryons, which are charged under the new symmetry. In this context, vector mesons assume the role of Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current is the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified picture for the two types of baryons, enabling them to transform into each other naturally. Additionally, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons, allowing for a deeper understanding of the underlying dynamics.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents a fascinating approach to integrating anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. Theoretically, we investigate how the superposition of these effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates substantial transverse Hall supercurrents, which we term anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. By extending the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially developed to quantify conventional Josephson current flows, we assess the transverse current components and show that their amplitudes can be broadly tuned via the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. Notably, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface, serving as a distinct spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions.

Following the suggestion from Monte-Carlo experiments in JimÃ©nez, J. of Turbul. (2020), which indicate that dipoles are as crucial to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is discovered that the kinetic energy of this flow is primarily carried by elongated streams formed through the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into two distinct families: small, fast-moving cores and larger, slowly moving ones that can be described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of both families differ significantly, with only the former exhibiting self-similarity. The latter family is responsible for most of the flow's kinetic energy, forming the dipoles and streams.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely useful framework for designing several quantum algorithms. The running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is often characterized by the quantum hitting time, which is the time required for the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. This article provides improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applicable to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. Notably, our techniques are applied to the glued-trees problem, yielding a polynomial factor improvement in the hitting time upper bound, from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Our methods also help to exponentially improve the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm for finding a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain by Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized into dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their distinct formation mechanisms. Dry EMRIs, previously considered the primary EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily generated through multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. This letter highlights an alternative EMRI formation channel: wet EMRI formation facilitated by the accretion flow surrounding accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH, significantly boosting the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about them, including no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social connections with other users. Despite this, we expect our recommender systems to engage users from the start, encouraging them to stay on the website and become active users. This challenge falls under the new user cold-start category, which is vital to a company's development and survival. Existing research on user cold-start recommendation often requires additional user effort, such as setting up an interview process, or utilizes side information like user demographics, locations, and social relations. However, users may be unwilling to participate in interviews, and side information on cold-start users is usually not available. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, e.g. Setting up an interview process, or make use of side information [10] such as user demographics, locations, social relations, etc.

Deep learning has resolved numerous problems that were previously inaccessible to heuristic algorithms. Its successful application in wireless communications is notable, despite the existence of well-understood radio systems and optimal algorithms for various tasks. Although learning individual receiver components has yielded some benefits, a more effective approach involves jointly learning the entire receiver. However, this often leads to a complex nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is impractical to implement. To address this, we introduce a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which processes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal streams to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. By carefully constructing the input of the convolutional neural network using both data and pilot symbols, we enable accurate channel estimation.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) from which to generate new inputs by mutation. A corpus of potential seeds often contains thousands of similar inputs, resulting in a lack of diversity that can lead to wasted fuzzing effort through exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) are used to select the smallest subset of seeds that triggers the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Minimizing the number and cumulative size of seeds is believed to lead to more efficient fuzzing. We present results of 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to understand their impact on finding bugs in real-world software, exploring this concept systematically.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation, where agents can be grouped based on similar state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into a common template. A scalable supervisor is designed, with state size and computational cost independent of the number of agents, for the case of partial observation. Notably, this supervisor does not require recomputation when agents are added or removed. We extend our previous results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor at the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis, demonstrating its effectiveness in multi-agent systems.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for ENF estimation is introduced, utilizing temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. The method leverages a type of Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix, exploiting its Toeplitz structure. Notably, this approach pioneers the use of a non-rectangular temporal window prior to spectral estimation in the field of ENF. Krylov matrices facilitate fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach surpasses state-of-the-art methods in ENF estimation when employing a short 1-second time window in power recordings. In speech recordings, the approach yields highly accurate results, balancing time complexity and accuracy.

The direpack package aims to integrate modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python universe as a single, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods are categorized into three groups: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are provided, including classical principal component regression and sparse partial robust M regression. The package also contains classical and robust pre-processing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, dedicated plotting functionality, and cross-validation utilities. The direpack package is written consistent with the scikit-learn API, allowing estimators to seamlessly integrate into statistical and machine learning pipelines in that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we studied the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. The fluorescence reduction was observed with high power laser excitation, increasing the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altering the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We employed a differential excitation protocol to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be used for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with defects in solids, offering a promising approach for future applications.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the conventional approach of using individual survey weights to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution, enabling unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters. This approach is compared to frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, revealing that only the Bayesian method achieves unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and a real data example from a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across various modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a culmination of recent efforts combining traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling paradigm, bridging the gap between these two rich but disparate sub-fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials, including res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene, exhibit more complex atomistic structures compared to the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. Their reduced symmetries lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, and large nonlinear optical properties. Additionally, low symmetry enables novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations. The "beyond graphene: low-symmetry and anisotropic 2D materials" special topic showcases recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials, also featuring photogalvanic effects and superconductivity.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. Notably, it was discovered that the relaxation of electric birefringence in a mesogenic polymer melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described by a sum of several exponential processes, with two dominant processes playing a crucial role. These primary processes replace each other within a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also revealed two distinct orientational relaxation processes: one attributed to the rotation of side mesogenic groups, and the other associated with the motion of main chain segments, providing a more detailed understanding of the polymer's behavior.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated exceptional retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in these methods. A common approach involves adopting an activation function, such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimizing a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm can cause hash bits to become stuck in the wrong saturated area of the activation functions, never escaping. We refer to this issue as the "dead bits problem" (dbp). The existing quantization loss can exacerbate dbp. In this paper, we introduce a simple yet effective gradient amplifier that precedes activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider two scenarios: stable triplets contributing to dark matter density, or unstable triplets decaying via mixing with the standard model Higgs boson. The former is constrained by LHC disappearing charged track searches and dark matter direct detection experiments. The latter is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. Our findings indicate that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches. Conversely, an unstable triplet with a mass below 230 GeV is excluded at a 95% confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings surrounding the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than anticipated in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, often referred to as "pericenter glow." The standard scenario assumes an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is increased to $e_f$ after the gas disc has dispersed due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. A minor modification to this scenario suggests that narrower belts can form if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, potentially resulting from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, a primordial eccentricity could also be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.

An electron is typically considered to possess only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, due to its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well-captured at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-Liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, along with the emergence of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that intensify with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1D inter-subband screening, which is adjusted by over 45%.

The assembly history of the Milky Way is being unveiled through data from the Gaia mission. The globular cluster system of our galaxy likely followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this path, we investigate the link between globular clusters and known merging events experienced by the Milky Way. We combined Gaia's kinematic information for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages, carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. Our results show that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ, shedding light on the complex formation history of the Milky Way's globular cluster system.

The estimation of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a crucial step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces intrinsic, an R package that implements state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of a dataset's intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package includes the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To facilitate easy access to these novel estimators, the package provides high-level, intuitive functions built on a set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models in two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The homogeneous category comprises the two-nn and gride models, with functions that perform inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The heterogeneous category includes hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented. The package's design allows for seamless integration of these models into various workflows.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems were proposed and modeled: one based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and the other on 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system predictions, respectively. Our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNO to current pulse stimulation showed that an RC system using a single MSM achieved outstanding performance in handwritten digits recognition. Furthermore, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems were effectively solved by a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOs, as confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. This paper identifies a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: when fewer items report a given signal, they collectively attract a higher share of overall traffic. The few-get-richer effect emerges in settings with few distinct item classes, such as left-leaning versus right-leaning news sources, where items are ranked by popularity. Analytically, we demonstrate that this effect occurs when people click on top-ranked items and have diverse preferences for item classes. We analyze the effect's strength through simulations, considering various setting and human behavior assumptions. Our predictions are experimentally tested in an online study with human participants. The findings have significant implications for understanding the spread of misinformation, particularly in settings with few distinct item classes and popularity-based rankings.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as a straightforward and effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), resulting in accelerated performance on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques involve trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, leading to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this issue, we introduce a novel sparsity dimension, pattern-based sparsity, which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity to achieve both high accuracy and hardware friendliness. By carefully designing patterns, our proposed pruning method consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and improved feature extraction capabilities across different DNN structures and datasets. Our pattern-aware pruning framework simultaneously performs pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training. The new pattern-based sparsity approach seamlessly integrates with compiler optimization, enabling highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from a treated group is susceptible to bias from historical events that have disparate effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may mitigate this bias. We investigate this phenomenon through simulation studies. We examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that leverages the increase in mrm following the 1990 clean air act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval that encompasses substantial adverse effects, no effect, and small beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for simulation purposes, it is good practice to assess their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved through visual predictive checks (vpc), which involve (1) multiple simulations of the original study using the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the original study's estimate. This procedure is a widely applicable, straightforward method. Here, we explore its application to time-to-event data, focusing on the special case where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are presented. We discuss how similar protocols, relying on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can be utilized to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence, consistent with Zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state through stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing filter functions in the frequency domain, driving the designed quantum sensor. These advancements will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, driving progress in quantum science and technologies.

I can't think of anyone who just has one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. Around 15 percent of American workers don't have traditional full-time jobs; they're half-time, part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term "side hustle" seems to fit with this ethos where people are combining multiple pursuits to make a living. The word "side hustle" originated in popular African American newspapers.
